22011: Rock Jockey.author: Laguz
22011: Rock Jockey.text_parsed:
It's not good, it's terrible. It took WotC forever to realize that nobody wants to buy card packs when there's a chance that there may be a completely useless card like this in it. A card that is useless even before the drawback...lol

I think the reaction to Kamigawa Block opened their eyes a bit. That whole block was 98% useless, 1% good, and 1% ridiculously broken. Starting with Ravnica block, the rock jockeys of the magic world have been thankfully scarce.

22011: Rock Jockey.author: A3Kitsune
22011: Rock Jockey.text_parsed:
@Laguz:

Rock Jockey isn't "useless even befor the drawback". He's a 3/3 for 3. Without the drawback, that's very good. Only green gets 3/3s for 3 without drawbacks (and gold, but they require two colors for their cost, which is a drawback of it's own). Yea, after the drawback, he's rather bad, but it's only the drawback that makes him bad.
And Kamigawa block was more overcosted/underpowered then outright useless.

41164: Unburden.author: GrimjawxRULES
41164: Unburden.text_parsed:
@AlphaNumerical: well, in mono black decks, this is strictly better than Mind Rot, because you can cycle it when you don't need it. In a multicolored deck, however, it is easier to splash for Mind Rot than for Unburden.

Overall a pretty decent card. Basically, it's a slightly less splashable Mind Rot, but the Cycling means that it'll never be a "dead" card - you can always replace it with a new card from the top of your deck.

If you're playing a competitive mono black deck, you should consider Hymn to Tourach instead, but this is fine for casual games when you don't want your games to be only about winning...

42024: Bladewing the Risen.author: WhiteWizard42
42024: Bladewing the Risen.text_parsed: Technically, if you Flash in Bladewing The Risen, he's sacrificed during spell resolution, before the ability triggers. Then, when you put his reanimation ability on the stack, he's already in the graveyard so he can target himself. So, Flash him in, sac him, he gets himself back in and then triggers to bring something else back with him.
42024: Bladewing the Risen.text_posted: Technically, if you [autocard]Flash[/autocard] in [autocard]Bladewing The Risen[/autocard], he's sacrificed during spell resolution, before the ability triggers. For a one-drop with a useful tribe, that's pretty awesome.

43513: Edgewalker.author: Stinga
43513: Edgewalker.text_parsed: Guys, rule 117.7a. of the Magic rules states "If a cost is reduced by an amount of coloured mana, but its colored mana component doesn't contain mana of that color, the cost is reduced by that amount of generic mana." If a cleric costs 1W and edgewalker is out that cleric costs 0. Guys, you can use this card with mono-coloured clerics.
43513: Edgewalker.text_posted: Guys, rule 117.7a. of the Magic rules states "If a cost is reduced by an amount of coloured mana, but its colored mana component doesn't contain mana of that color, the cost is reduced by that amount of generic mana." If a cleric costs 1W and edgewalker is out that cleric costs 0. Guys, you can use this card with mono-coloured clerics.

43513: Edgewalker.author: MacBizzle
43513: Edgewalker.text_parsed:
I've browsed online for years, and this is the only mana reducer card (among warchieves, familiars, and artifacts) that reduces colored costs. Conspiracy and other tribal modifiers are cool in conjunction, along with a Stormscape Familiar. But, I've been looking through early blue instants to see if there's one to change mana symbols on a card (ala Sleight of Mind)...

5/5 for a combo-ing aspect.

Edit: Hate to ruin my high rated comment, but I gotta correct Stinga here.

That rule is awesome, and you made me hope for a moment. Because this is the only card I've found that reduces colored costs. However, that rule is rendered useless. This card states SPECIFICALLY that his cost reduction can only be applied to colored mana, then goes so far to give an example in the form of good ol' reminder text, to alleviate the confusion your comment may cause. It still reads this way in the Oracle text (but here's hoping for a change; I'm emailing Wizards about this), and the FIRST golden rule of magic is:

101.1. Whenever a card's text directly contradicts these rules, the card takes precedence. The card overrides only the rule that applies to that specific situation. The only exception is that a player can concede the game at any time (see rule 104.3a).

So, no, he does not reduce colorless costs. He *should* be errata-ed, considering that the rule you mentioned pretty much should only apply to him, and that he would be DOWNRIGHT NASTY, but the card rules take precedence over the comprehensive rules, as stated by the comprehensive rules.

43515: Zombie Cutthroat.author: majinara
43515: Zombie Cutthroat.text_parsed:
I guess the point of this guy is that it's a 3/4 zombie for three colorless mana, that is likely to cause card disadvantage for your opponent. You play the guy and attack or block without any mana left, and your opponent might block with a 2/2 or 3/3 or whatever assuming that you can't unmorph the guy. Then your guy kills the attacker or blocker. Or survives a shock or lightning bolt.

So, while not a particularily good card, a 3/4 for three mana that might cause an opponent to waste cards is ok, despite the drawback.

43533: Dragon Breath.author: majinara
43533: Dragon Breath.text_parsed:
Great card.
- it's cheap so can be played early on
- makes late game still sense, since you can pump all excess mana into the firebreathing effect
- returns to play for free
- gives your fatties what they need most (next to trample): haste

Also great in team games, where you can play it (or return it) on a teammates creature. And then you can spend your mana on firebreathing up your teammates creature.

43533: Dragon Breath.author: Mode
43533: Dragon Breath.text_parsed:
Easily the best card of the dragon aura cycle (which would be breath, fangs, scales, shadow, wings.)

Even without the firebreathing it would still be awesome, since giving haste to your big guy without spending mana alone is already a great thing.

Since you have to get this card in your graveyard somehow (if you don't want to simply cast it on another creature first and wait for it to die) consider using good old Anger instead when running mono-red, or a deck that can add mountains without problems.
43533: Dragon Breath.text_posted:
Easily the best card of the dragon aura cycle (which would be breath, [autocard multiverseid="47165"]fangs[/autocard], [autocard multiverseid="44400"]scales[/autocard], [autocard multiverseid="45155"]shadow[/autocard], [autocard multiverseid="46427"]wings[/autocard].)

43543: One with Nature.author: Powerofone
43543: One with Nature.text_parsed:
This card actually has quite a few uses -- there's the obvious option of sticking it onto something with trample or the like, but you could also put it onto one of your opponent's early creatures. This means they will think twice about attacking and giving you early mana advantage.

Or, stick it on a bigger creature, and make them again think twice about attacking. Then, when they do attack, you can choose whether or not to let it through (putting it on something with trample and then blocking all but 1 damage each time would be optimal). So, your opponent attacks --> you profit.

43555: Misguided Rage.author: sarroth
43555: Misguided Rage.text_parsed:
@Fenix: Except Lhurgoyf's flavor text says that Saffi Eriksdotter (the flavor text being her last words, after all) died and yet Saffi Eriksdotter was printed in Time Spiral. Not that a Time Spiral 2 will ever happen, but if it did, there's not reason it couldn't involve an alternate timeline where Furt was the one with the Misguided Rage and Varv is the one that dies, or where instead of dying Furt's spark ignites and he becomes a planeswalker.

A red card that can possibly get rid of enchantments. There aren't many of those... Like Tyrant of Discord, it's unlikely enough that it will result in the removal of an enchantment that even color pie purist Mark Rosewater would be okay with it. It's too bad that it doesn't instead read "Choose creature, artifact, or land: Target opponent sacrifices a card of the chosen type" instead, as it would give you more control over what they have to lose, even if you wouldn't be able to get an enchantment that way.

Phyrexian Unlife

In order to win, your opponent will have to deal you damage down to zero life or less, and then, later on the same turn, will have to deal you at least 10 more damage. And they'll have only a few turns to draw a Disenchant or to gather the rare combination of direct damage and/or flying creatures (divided as necessary between first strikers and non-first-strikers) to pull it off.

43566: Form of the Dragon.author: orisiti
43566: Form of the Dragon.text_parsed:
@Scott... it is a triggered ability (Triggers on your upkeep starting)
@Pedro... I think what he was trying to convey the fact that they have to do damage two seperate times each turn... each turn you get that five life back, meaning that you will once again absorb the combat damage...
To Clarify the combo... All combat damage is dealt at once (unless there is first or double strikers on the field) lets use do damage as an example... so your life total is >0 so the dammage is dealt normally... 5-20 = -15. At the end of the turn, you gain 20 life. The only way you ill accumulate poison is if they use burn to deal 5 damage to you before combat, use burn after dealing the five damage in combat, or dealing at least 5 first strike damage. (Multiple combats, or just using infect creatures work as well0

43569: Dragon Mage.author: DarthParallax
43569: Dragon Mage.text_parsed:
This is maybe the only Dragon 'serious' Kaalia players will consider anymore.

Johnnies who had to think 'how do we make this EVEN dumber' came up with this tho: Scion of the Ur-Dragon, slide Kaalia to the 99. 5-color, 3-tribe, super broken bonkers deck? ENABLED.

EDIT: Hmm....i was thinking that after Griselbrand and Gisela were spoiled, that AVR would give so many great Angels and Demons, that Dragons would be too hard to find room for. I was wrong though- they've definitely made some competitive worthy Dragons since then, and a little number of Old Dragons still have teeth enough to be worth looking at-- but I do think Dragons are more likely to be outdated by Newer cards than Angels (who will always have Akroma and now Avacyn) or Demons (who will probably always have Reiver Demon and definitely always Griselbrand and Rakdos, the Defiler).

This is the only Dragon I think is unlikely to get outdated anytime soon though, the way other cards look. Big Fat Flyers that Don't Die and Wreck Stuff- that's not hard or uncommon to see designs for either in a single card or in easy combinations- but Card Draw- that's a very different story for Red/White/Black. If you aren't playing something Necropotence-like, you're probably playing this. You might even play both.

43578: Riptide Survivor.author: Nagoragama
43578: Riptide Survivor.text_parsed:
The reason he looks so strange is that during the Onslaught block (in which he was originally printed) the Mirari, an incredibly powerful artifact that grants the desires of its possessor, has been stuck into the ground of the Krosan Forest. This causes the Mirari to leak its power into the surrounding land; eventually pulses of magic from the Mirari reach the entirety of the continent of Otaria. This has a warping effect on its inhabitants: they become exaggerated versions of themselves. Soldiers become hugely-musclebound and lose their mouths, elves become massive, almost tree-like beings covered in vines, and wizards become fluid, almost water-like beings made of energy.

However for the most part, mechanically, the cards themselves retain their original creature type, though some gain the "mutant" creature type, as well.

43578: Riptide Survivor.author: vantha
43578: Riptide Survivor.text_parsed:
I really like this idea, and it probably deserves its own keyword, Call it 'Filter' in recent sets the ability has gone to Red and I understand why. You are discarding then drawing so you have no idea if you are getting value out of your cards, while Blue draws then discards 'Looter' hence you know the card you know in advance which cards are good to keep and which to discard.

In a Perfect world creatures like Red and Blue would have:
When this creature is turned face up Filter 2, Discard 2 cards then draw 2 cards or
When this creature is turned face up Loot 2, Draw 2 cards, then discard 2 cards
43578: Riptide Survivor.text_posted:
I really like this idea, and it probably deserves its own keyword, Call it '[b]Filter[/b]' in recent sets the ability has gone to Red and I understand why. You are discarding then drawing so you have no idea if you are getting value out of your cards, while Blue draws then discards '[b]Looter[/b]' hence you know the card you know in advance which cards are good to keep and which to discard. 

In a Perfect world creatures like Red and Blue would have:
When this creature is turned face up Filter 2, Discard 2 cards then draw 2 cards       or
When this creature is turned face up Loot 2, Draw 2 cards, then discard 2 cards

43581: Pemmin's Aura.author: adrian.malacoda
43581: Pemmin's Aura.text_parsed: Spellskite? That won't work. If you give Spellskite shroud then it becomes an illegal target, meaning you can't redirect anything to it.
43581: Pemmin's Aura.text_posted: Spellskite? That won't work. If you give Spellskite shroud then it becomes an illegal target, meaning you can't redirect anything to it.

43581: Pemmin's Aura.author: IUHoosier
43581: Pemmin's Aura.text_parsed:
Ahem.

Spellskite.

That is all.

@adrian.malacoda: Depends on the order that you redirect the spell/ability and activate Pemmin's Aura. You activate Pemmin's Aura giving Spellskite shroud, then on the stack you redirect the spell/ability to Spellskite. Spellskite's ability resolves first and redirects the spell/ability, then Pemmin's Aura's ability resolves and gives Spellskite shroud, then the spell/ability tries to resolve but can't, and the spell/ability fizzles.
43581: Pemmin's Aura.text_posted:
Ahem.

[autocard]Spellskite[/autocard].

That is all.

#8 Ghostform Temporary.
#9 Steel of the Godhead Permanent, expensive.

43586: Undead Warchief.author: Sorain
43586: Undead Warchief.text_parsed:
The staple main card of my Black Zombie deck for years. Not only is he cheap for his basic stats (being a 3/2 for 2BB) but he not only strengthen's virtually every creature in my deck. (Festering Goblin is now a 3/2, Gravecrawler a 4/2, ect) but he helps accelerate the rest of the army coming out. (paying 4 for Noxious Ghoul Corpse Harvester quickly adds up the advantage) Where he really shines is with things like Unbreathing Horde which remains in play with 0 counters and can't take damge anymore, or evasive creatures like Severed Legion also handy if you have 4 out to end things with a 3 mana Zombie Brute.

That being said, Undead Warcheif tends to eat a lot of damage or removal spells. Of course, that can be exactly what you want at times. A Path to Exile spent on him is unavailble for other things like Phage the Untouchable or Soulless One, a lightning bolt spent on him is not hitting you in the face, and in combination with recursion such as Oversold Cemetery , a Lord of the Undead or Volrath's Stronghold nothing short of Exile will help much.

So yes, an oldie but a goodie.

This is terrible in a goblins deck. Playing this on turn 3 is usually one of the worst things everâ€“it's cool to get the pseudo-Arc Lightning effect, but then you drop to 1 mountain? Instead of being able to play multiple Goblins on the next turn or a useful goblin, you're stuck with probably a terrible mana base.

If you're running this with Skirk Alarmist, then you aren't building a goblins deck, but a morph deck. If that's the case, I guess this might be okay... It just seems like there are simpler ways to get this kind of effect. I guess it could still be card advantage.

43591: Goblin Warchief.author: blurrymadness
43591: Goblin Warchief.text_parsed:
Krenko works amazing with this guy; as does Goblin Warrens, Goblin Lookout, and such.

Basically; you get a huge attacking force that they didn't see coming and it all gets +2/+0;

Example:
Brightstone ritual into Krenko T4, tap for 4-5 goblins (which have haste)
Use your remaining mana to put the lookout out, sac a goblin (possibly krenko) for +2/+0

Now you attack with something like 8 goblins who are all at least +3/+0, if not bigger. That's an additional ~25 damage I bet your opponent wasn't expecting.

43604: Parallel Thoughts.author: ClockworkSwordfish
43604: Parallel Thoughts.text_parsed: This card is excellent, but if you approach it like a Tutor you'll be disappointed. This isn't meant to fetch one card; if you use it thus you'll probably die waiting to draw that one Darksteel Colossus you know you have coming. Instead, it essentially lets you stack your deck for the next seven draws. If it's comparatively early in the game, get combo pieces, chump blockers, even lands; anything that will benefit you. If it's later in the game and you have the resources, go ahead and fetch the Colossi and Cloudscrapers and what-have-you. This card is incredibly versatile, and that makes it good.

43604: Parallel Thoughts.author: DocDoom
43604: Parallel Thoughts.text_parsed:
@everyone who thinks you can fail to find cards: You can only fail to find Cards if they have specific charectristics (eg, being "Basic Lands"). If you are told to find any card, without any characteristics specified, you have to find them.

The reason why you are allowed to fail to find cards with certain properties is because they are hidden to your opponent: In general, your opponent has no way of knowing if there are really not enough cards with the required property to find for you.

Lets say, there are only two artifacts in your deck. You have a card that tells you to search for three artifacts. How do you prove that there are only two artifacts in your deck? Show your whole deck to your opponent?

Thats why you are allowed to say: "Okay, there are only these two artifacts in my deck. I can't find a third artifact."

But since you cant prove that fact (because the content of your deck is hidden to your opponent) , your opponent can not prove the opposite, ie that there are in fact five artifacts in your deck, and that you are lying by saying that there are only two.

But Cards with undefined characteristics can just be counted, so you can't lie and say "I only have four cards in my deck", while shuffling 40+ cards.

43604: Parallel Thoughts.author: Lyoncet
43604: Parallel Thoughts.text_parsed: Real backfire potential if played against enchantment removal or bounce, and a bit pricey, but it can really work wonders under the right circumstances. For example, if you have a nasty little combo that you can pull off with any 2 of 3 cards, exile 2, 2, and 3 of each part of the combo; the odds of you drawing the same one twice in a row are pretty low, and the odds of you drawing the same one three in a row are pretty much negligible. Or, you could use the land-thinning mentioned to cut the number of lands you likely have left in your deck by around half and call them up on-demand. Or, you could just exile whatever you feel like exiling and watch your mill-happy opponent tear his/her hair out (assuming, again, no enchantment hate or bounces). And of course cards like Brainstorm just absolutely break this card.

43604: Parallel Thoughts.author: Lord_Ascapelion
43604: Parallel Thoughts.text_parsed:
What is with everyone saying "strictly better" or "strictly worse" when it's clearly not true? This card and Mangara's Tome have enough differences where you can't say that one would be strictly better than the other in any situation. This gets more cards, Mangara's Tome is an artifact and requires mana, this card requires BLUE mana, etc., etc..

Seriously guys, "strictly better" means that in almost every possible situation (barring incredibly narrow niche situations), one card would be better than the other- for example, Lightning Bolt is strictly better than Shock. There is essentially no reason to play Shock over Lightning Bolt. However, there might be any number of factors that might lead one to play this card over Mangara's Tome, or vice versa.

Seriously, there's nothing wrong with saying a card is just "better" or if you want to be more specific, "generally better."

43605: Long-Term Plans.author: Names_Suck
43605: Long-Term Plans.text_parsed:
This is essentially a more versatile Mystical Tutor for 2 more CMC.

There are too many ways in blue to get 3rd from the top for this to be rated at 3. Preordain, Ponder, Impulse, the aforementioned mental note or any of the tons of draw 2+ will get the card you wanted on your next turn. Or with Ancestrall Recall or one of its weaker clones you can get the card you wanted on your opponents turn.

With the restriction on mystical tutor, it should be higher rated than 3. And should really see more play than it does. To me Long-Term Plans is comparable to Mystical Teachings, Intuition, and Gifts Ungiven. The first being limited in choice, more cost but replayable, the last 2 being counterable by GY removal for combos or strips your deck of something good if you grab all the same.

Also, the flavor is awesome, so for me 5/5.

43605: Long-Term Plans.author: yyukichigai
43605: Long-Term Plans.text_parsed:
Fun fact: this is the only non-permanent blue spell other than Intuition that will let you search your library for any card, rather than limiting you to a specific subset (e.g. instants, sorceries, etc.). Also its instant-speed, meaning you can use it at the end of your opponent's turn to offset the delay slightly.

A perfect card for Blue control. If you can survive through three draws you can get access to whatever it is you need to win the game.

43605: Long-Term Plans.author: dberry02
43605: Long-Term Plans.text_parsed:
Things that make this card really good:

1. Fetches any card.
2. Doesn't reveal the chosen card.
3. Instant speed.

This card is extremely good in EDH where searching for Enchantments or Planeswalkers can be difficult. The only real downside of this card (other than having to wait a few turns) is that it locks down your deck from any kind of searching.

Drawing, Scrying, or Milling yourself will negate all downsides - making this one of the best tutors in blue. I give this card a 4.5/5 for its sheer potential.

43605: Long-Term Plans.author: raptorman333
43605: Long-Term Plans.text_parsed:
Compared to Diabolic Tutor, they put it in blue, they reduced the mana cost by 1 strict mana, they put it at instant speed, and the only side effect is that it doesn't put it right into your hand, it puts it 3rd from the top... in a color that has never known to have problems drawing cards... or getting card advantage for that matter.
Basically what you can do with this in its simplest, aside for just waiting for it, you already grabbed card advantage now you use that extra card to brainstorm with this and, BAM! you just not only pulled out the card for a straight tutor, but you also fixed two cards in your hand. I'm sorry that you were expecting Demonic Tutor at instant speed--that card was a rare and it's probably never getting printed again. If you want straight pull to hand use the already commented Mystical Teachings, Intuition, and Gifts Ungiven. Want to break the card? Oath of druids.
4.5/5

43606: Thundercloud Elemental.author: PureLiquidAwesome
43606: Thundercloud Elemental.text_parsed:
Everyone complaining about this card costing too much needs to remember that this card was designed for Ons/Leg/Scg limited, and one of the themes in Scourge was converted mana cost matters. Being a seven mena flier, with two abilitites that remove blocks actually istn't all that bad in that context. It's first ability breaks board stalls, and the second creates inevitability. This card seems fine for the limited environment it was designed for.

Outside of that, unless you're trying to get cute with Sorceress Queen type effects, it's really not doing much . . . .

43615: Soul Collector.author: BegleOne
43615: Soul Collector.text_parsed:
It doesn't require combat damage, so you could combo it with a Timchantment like Hermetic Study, Psionic Gift or Arcane Teachings. It would work great because you could use it on your own creatures as they go to the graveyard in addition to your opponents creatures as they go to the graveyard. You can even ping a guy, sacrifice it and still get it back. A very powerful effect.

With that in mind, it can be an even more effective two-card combo than a Tim with a Charisma in the right deck. And, it has morph. And, it is a vampire from before vampires were hyper-efficient infringes on white creatures.

And, also... Well, the art is racy as hell. It demands to be mentioned and appreciated.

43711: Dragon Tyrant.author: Asarkun
43711: Dragon Tyrant.text_parsed:
way to expensive. If you get one attack with this guy and your opponent has no removal or something like that, you won most of the games but... seriously. 10 Mana is hard to get and when you have it, it can be countered for 2 Mana and your whole mana is spend for nothing. Of course you can counter nearly everthing but if this is countered you cant play anything great that turn and you are defenseless in the opponents turn.

So if you get him on the playfield and you attack you are even more screwed if your opponent has a remover because you spend 4 mana for it to survive at the beginning of your upkeep and maybe some more to boost it. So you spent about 14-18 mana what left you nearly defenseless for 2 opponent turns and your opponent needs only 2-3 mana to get this guy into the graveyard.

Needless to say that if you dont have 10 mana you dont want to draw this card.

43711: Dragon Tyrant.author: Laguz
43711: Dragon Tyrant.text_parsed:
I don't think anyone is going to look at this card and say "wow, this is going to win me some tournaments." People look at this and say "wow, this is going to be a lot of fun." As long as they still know how to have fun, that is...

These are the best kinds of magic cards if you ask me. No needlessly overcomplicated rules text, no errata, no broken cheese, no "omg i found a loophole in the rules that lets me break this"...just pure, unadulterated fun.

Also, the artwork is amazing. Kev Walker is amazing.

43711: Dragon Tyrant.author: Nuclear_Pony
43711: Dragon Tyrant.text_parsed:
It's not too expensive provided that you have ways around it's rediculous castings cost.
My mono red all dragon deck packs 4 Dragonspeaker Shamans and 4 Urza's incubators and theoretically my dragons are 12 colourless mana cheaper.
That means you only have to worry about the red mana.
Or you can play green and add some Elvish Pipers in the deck (as someone here mentioned earlier), something worth considering (even by me, who rather keeps his creature themed-decks mono-coloured).
And if you are still too worried about your dragons being too expensive...Well, you have got to be extremely desperate but you can also add 4 copies of Ruby Medallion (wich makes your red dragons another 4 colourless mana cheaper). But I'm sure no one here is THAT DESPERATE :D

43711: Dragon Tyrant.author: allmighty_abacus
43711: Dragon Tyrant.text_parsed:
I ran this guy in a R/G land destruction deck as a late game beatstick, and he was more often than not how I won. It's really hard to respond to a win condition suddenly showing up or taking advantage of the tyrants' drawback if you have no lands.

Of course, this was back in the days of yore when stone rain and the like were actually feasible and not too slow. And also before everyone in my playgroup got all hurr type 2 tourneymode.

All in all, I love this card. He shows up and says "alright you worthless ape! I'm going to win you this fight, but you had better pay me tribute or I'll leave your sorry arse!!!"

43717: Twisted Abomination.author: ClockworkSwordfish
43717: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
This was the second card I ever got, and boy is it great! A 5/3 is nothing special, but a 5/anything with regeneration hits hard and is tricky to deal with. This makes it a good creature once you play it, but it's a bit pricey. The swampcycling, thus, is what really makes this card. You can get a swamp now, and reanimate it later. If you return it to your hand later instead of straight to the battlefield, you can swampcycle it again! Great in many ways. Almost forgot; great art too.

Two reprints say that Wizards agrees with me on this card's excellence.

43717: Twisted Abomination.author: blurrymadness
43717: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
Ah! I didn't comment on this printing! How suitable I comment on this one with great news:
I recently won some legacy games off of this guy's back. The swampcycling helps mana fix (dual lands) and ensure early lands in a deck that only runs 21-22, and the giant ass means he is a big pain for the opponent.

He unfortunately was dropped for now; but his wins against decks running Goyf and Batterskull show she's still relevant due to his versatility and requiring an exile-answer or a sac effect. Ran him next to Eternal Witness for easy recursion and lots of other guys who ramp/grab lands.

My opponent was not happy about losing to a Scourge Common; but I was ecstatic to see such a cheap ($0.25 or so) creature help *make* my deck. Amazing :)

43725: Call to the Grave.author: CXA26483
43725: Call to the Grave.text_parsed: As much as I love this card (and play it as a 3-of in my zombie deck), I have to say, it's high mana cost prevents it from being truly effective. Albeit it's probably right (5cc for a one sided Abyss? Can't complain...), cast it too early, suffer the consequences of having to sac. it due to lack of creatures in play. Cast too late, suffer the consequences of countering or destruction. Overall though, I still think it's playable, especially if you have a small control build (comboing in cards like Unliving Psychopath and Fleshbag Marauder to wipe your opponent's fields while you attack away with your Undead Warchiefs or Soulless Ones).
43725: Call to the Grave.text_posted: As much as I love this card (and play it as a 3-of in my zombie deck), I have to say, it's high mana cost prevents it from being truly effective. 43725: Call to the Grave.author: Zulp
43725: Call to the Grave.text_parsed: Obviously brutal in an all-zombie deck. Essentially everyone else will instantly hate you if you manage to get it out, even other black players that aren't playing zombies, which is what really pushes this card over the edge for me. Sometimes it can be hard to control black players because of the limits of removal spells, but this can work around it. Superb card, all around. 4.5/5.

Anyway, good card. 4/5, because it's pretty brutal in a zombie deck, but can be dealt with fairly easily if you know what you're doing.

43727: Lingering Death.author: sincleanser
43727: Lingering Death.text_parsed:
First:
AXER - Doom Blade does not obsolete Terror for the simple fact that Terror doesn't allow regen. Artifact creatures can be a pain, but in my playgroup, regen is much more prevalent than dangerous artifact creatures. They do do similar things, but I would forever take Terror over Doom Blade any day. Plus, Terror is better named and has better art overall

Second: This is the third option of the black mage, it's essentially the same thing, but not. A very big difference here is that the creature is sacrificed, not destroyed. This gets around all that stupid indestructible crap that's out now. It also gets around the normal restriction of targeting that black has, meaning it can hit black or artifact creatures along with everything else. The only real downside that this has is two fold - it's delayed long enough that they can still attack with it for one turn and its the same cost as most of blacks key removal.

43727: Lingering Death.author: MtFrostM
43727: Lingering Death.text_parsed:
Grasp of Darkness is better than all four of those in mono-black.

Most creatures you're facing wouldn't be bigger than 4/4.

If it is, it's probably their only creature, in which Innocent Blood or Diabolic/Cruel Edict is better since it gets around protection/shroud. If they have big and small, deal with the smaller first and kill the big, if they have two (or more) big ones, then you want damnation or you're just screwed.

If you're facing blue, Sudden Death is preferred.

Me? I run 4x Grasp and 4x Innocent. Works out a lot better. Targeted kill is overkill 90% of the time.

43729: Rush of Knowledge.author: KillerWhiskey
43729: Rush of Knowledge.text_parsed:
In casual, this works extremely well with either suspend or affinity. Basically any creature in play can net you five or more cards. I use it in a suspend deck, and there it performs amazingly. Why bother with combos if you can make it more consistent?

In a right setup, it rarely fizzles, but it can and will happen on occasion. This is the case when you're either without counters or you top-deck it on an empty board. However, I'd say the card advantage it provides makes it worth this small risk. This is typically the scenario:

Riftwing Cloudskate, Errant Ephemeron or Deep-Sea Kraken are just entering the battlefield, or Spire Golem is entering for free on the sixth land. Attack if you can first to probe for kill spells, then cast this. I use Misdirection for cover because it can be cast for free (you can use Force of Will, but I don't have a playset), and if multiple creatures enter at once, there's usually no need for it. Take note that creatures are entering on YOUR turn FOR FREE, so 90% of mass kill spells can't be cast on time, and usually the cards you net with this provide you with even more cover and/or more creatures and/or another Rush of Knowledge, making it exponentially more difficult for your opponent to deal with it. Having non-creature cards on the side, perhaps a Jace, the Mind Sculptor, also help to prevent this from fizzling, and at least make it worth your while on a Tidings level.

I'd say it's a solid 4/5, but only for casual games. With the current meta-game, I don't see it work that well on a competitive level because it demands a very specific deck build - the kind where aggro is going to tear you apart.

43733: Metamorphose.author: CeremonialBathory
43733: Metamorphose.text_parsed:
@garbagegatherer- This would be fine with Radiate. Let's say your opponent has out 10 permanents. You'd target all of them, and then he'd put up to 10 cards in to play. Is it likely he'll have 10 cards in hand? No. Is it likely he's holding all permanents and no instants or sorceries? No. It isn't an instant win play, no. But it's funny and it will usually give you board position. Twitch and Radiate is also a good combo, so I'm not saying you're wrong about that.

That said, this card by itself isn't that great of an idea. Bouncing one permanent that they've already been able to play for and giving them something in their hand they couldn't afford yet is a bad idea.

You could also mix with things that hurt them somehow on casting (costing extra mana, bouncing permanents, losing life, etc..)

Basically you slow their tempo (if done right) stay card neutral, and deny the opponent much needed answers they may be seeking. Again, use this LATE game, not just when you have the mana.

43733: Metamorphose.author: RunedServitor
43733: Metamorphose.text_parsed:
There should be a R/B enchantment called Self-Loathing that reads, "You count as your own opponent." That would combo with a bunch of cards, including this one, and you could build a wacky but wonderful deck around it. I'm actually kind of surprised something like that wasn't printed in New Phyrexia, considering all the other weird no-good-on-its-own combo fodder they printed in that block.

And no, HorseMittens, you can't Redirect this onto one of your own creatures, because Redirect can only change the target of a spell to a target it could have legally targeted to begin with, and normally, you aren't your own opponent. =(

43733: Metamorphose.author: Cyberium
43733: Metamorphose.text_parsed:
Magic is about making a combination of cards work, not to judge a card only by its text.

Consider this combo: imprint Meta on Isochron Scepter, use discard spells to empty opponent's hand, then proceed to lock them down every turn with a meta by putting their land on top of the library. Use walls like Wall of Denial to block which ever creature they manage to put into play. Or, have spells ready to destroy the permanent accordingly with Oblivion Ring
43733: Metamorphose.text_posted:
Magic is about making a combination of cards work, not to judge a card only by its text.

Consider this combo: imprint Meta on [autocard]Isochron Scepter[/autocard], use discard spells to empty opponent's hand, then proceed to lock them down every turn with a meta by putting their land on top of the library. 43734: Skulltap.author: Gezus82
43734: Skulltap.text_parsed:
why the hell is this rated so low? this card is amazing in my mono black sacrifice deck.

my normal course of action with this is sack bloodghast, trigger mortician beetle, pawn of ulamog and grave pact. And of course I normally draw a land to get bloodghast back.

so I get 2 cards, a +1/+1 counter, an edict, and a spawn token, for just 2 manna.


Now of course this card might not always be that good but for some small creature or one that likes going in the graveyard like sprouting thrinax, academy rector, etc... or something like bloodghast or vengevine that can just come back are a decent trade for 2 life, but most importantly a more easily manageable casting cost over sign in blood.

this card is good cuz it gets you 2 cards cheaply, but can also be used as an engine to do other cool things.

44263: Karona, False God.author: Zoah
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
Virtually useless. Looks cool, but not really. (I guess that's why she's a FALSE god) I think this is possibly one of the least useful cards I have ever seen.

First, her color weight is huge, and her converted manna cost outweighs her stats, although her having hast is nice. I don't know... if she were a great deal cheaper than she might actually be sort of not garbage.

The only hope to use her well is either an odd combo based deck or as a last ditch effort to end the game.

So, without wasting any more time on her, her base rating: ***

color weight: -*
Power up trick: +*
side switcher: -**
combo? +*/2

Final: * */2

44263: Karona, False God.author: SorianSadaskan
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
What makes her unique than her previous counterparts (Phage and Akroma) is that while they can literally fight on their own, Karona instead lead and command an army of her own as the story dictates. Imagine controlling a mob and able to pump them up by +3/+3 at each players turn is highly dangerous as her ability can be swing back at you, but hey, such is the price of power.

The difficulty is trying to assemble these colors, most creature decks only operate on two to three colors instead of five. The exception lies with Slivers and Allies.

Don't laugh, because a lot of people didn't anticipate certain minority players to play slivers with Karona to lead in the attack. I admit, she's not amazing at first sight, but true players know her potentials when it's conducted in combat.

44263: Karona, False God.author: Revan312
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
Two cards make her amazing and that's Eon Hub and Conspiracy.

I made a pretty devastating token deck where all the tokens are mixed; saprolings, soldiers, thrulls etc. Once you have Eon Hub and Conspiracy out I slap out Karona and basically win at that point unless they have something to either counter her or kill me outright, maybe a stop all combat damage spell..

Overall, from her own set, she's garbage, but mix her with the above mentioned cards and she becomes epic for a token deck..

44263: Karona, False God.author: ICEFANG13
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
I greatly dislike this card.

Ideally, you will need a deck that:

Is tribal, most decks have better lords already as long as the tribe is of real size, with the new super lord Adaptive Automaton, it it less useful to use this temp +3/+3

Can remove the main disadvantage, even if they aren't playing a tribal deck, you'll be getting smashed for 8 (since they may choose Avatar), you will need some walls or health gain to resist it (since you don't want to trade or eat her)

Is probably EDH, increasing the ability to play it, otherwise you will have a deck devoted to it, and aren't playing it.

Here are some 5 color tribes
Elementals, you want to play Horde of Notions probably though.
Scarecrows, you want to play Reaper King probably though.
Slivers.... yeah you don't want to use Karona for that.
Atogs, you may want to use Atogatog instead, but you may prefer a semi +3/+3 instead.
Dragons, this is one of the better ones, you can eat Karona if you want, although there are an abundance of multicolored dragons, there is only 1 Legendary WUBRG Scion of the Ur-Dragon, the +3/+3 may be better.

However, in something I feel is kinda ironic, Karona is PERFECT for an avatar tribe deck:
Acts as a permanent +3/+3 to your creatures (if the opponent wants to hit with Karona) or he can only use a different creature, which helps remove the drawback of getting hit for 8.

Anyway, that's the best use I can think of, she is great for avatar decks, just good luck with making one.

44263: Karona, False God.author: OmegaSerris
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
She HAD to have haste. If not, she would permanently be stuck in summoning sickness.

Nobody would have had control of her since the beginning of their turn. Sort of like if you mind control something an opponent played the turn before, you can't attack with it until YOUR next turn. And if they naturalize it on their turn, they have to wait once more. On Karona, it would never end as long as she kept getting passed around.

Anyways, I like where they were going with her, but I think the fell short. Granted, creatures in her time weren't as flashy as they are today. But she needed more of a boost to hold that 'false idol' feel. Something to tempt players to try and take advantage of her, yet to be betrayed in the end. The tribal battle cry is nice and all, but falls short of "Break me!" especially with that mana cost. I know she was behind all of the insanely powerful Decrees (Powerful, I didn't say mana efficient) but yet, this all she'll do for you?

44263: Karona, False God.author: DarthParallax
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
Karona should have been in FTV: Legends.....except for the part where she sucks a$$ compared to pProgenitus.


She is a 5/5 for 6 mana, in 5 colors. Dragons can get 5/5 for 5 mana in one color on a good day these days, and even Blue had some pretty heavy flyers on the cheap EVEN back in the day when blue was supposed to have crappy creatues (they usually had drawbacks)

I don't remember how much power Phage had because it didn't matter. Akroma was a 6/6. I firmly believe that the first correction this card needs is to be made a 7/7 with flying, so that it can successfully block and kill Akroma if you have a card to remove her 'protection from...' abilities.

The second thing I suggest is that they actually use the mechanic they were thinking about putting on Akroma: ''Whenever this creature dies, return it to the battlefield under its owner's control." I also think that they should have keyworded it- and called it Immortal.

An Immortal 7/7 flier might be enough. After all, we are not trying to just make another Super Voltron. It would make Akroma less special. Karona wants to be short, elegant, and to the point with her abilities to have the most aesthetically pleasing contrast with Akroma and Phage; and being 5-colored is quite snazzy just on its own.

The third thing I suggest is this: Creatures you control get +1/+1. An Omni-Lord would feel fairly appropriate for a God-Spirit-Avatar-Incarnation of Mana. You also want to remember what this ends up looking like to a Designer FROM BACK THEN. They've changed so much about how they think since, that it would be flat out wrong to try to make Karona what she could have been if they'd designed her at the time they were making Commander or FTV: Legends.


Karona, the False God

Creature- Legend

Flying
Creatures you control get +1/+1
Immortal (Whenever this creature dies, return it to
the battlefield under its owner's control.)

At the beginning of your upkeep, target opponent
gains control of Karona, the False God.

7/7

This is a huge what-if. We will never know. But I like my 'fixed' Karona quite a bit,
since I think it keeps what is good and changes only what is not good about the original :)

44263: Karona, False God.author: ProbablyThatGuy
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
Another fun cycle to throw in her EDH deck is the Dragon enchantments from Scourge:
Dragon Breath
Dragon Fangs
Dragon Scales
Dragon Shadow
Dragon Wings

Once you have all 5 in the yard, she enters and gains all of them, becoming a 9/8 Haste, Flying, Trample, Vigilance (will rarely matter though), Firebreathing, Fear creature that pumps a tribe by +3/+3 when it swings. Practical? Hell no. Cool to watch work out in casual? Of course. Just make sure you are able to deal with the mess you've made, since you'll be passing her around once the turn is over.

Bonus point if you grab them all with Conflux and give a long "by our powers combined" speech.

44263: Karona, False God.author: Enelysios
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
EDH, changeling and the vows (Vow of Wildness) have finally given this legend a place to call home. Keep in mind this is a decade after her printing. When she was released, she was gag-inducingly bad, and to add insult to pulling her as a rare, she is the culmination of the awesome Phage the untouchable (Who does manage to be far worse in EDH I suppose) and Akroma, Angel of Wrath.So following two blocks of awe-inspiring legends that did new things and pushed the boundaries of what a beatdown creature could be we got this.

Thats right folks, you run five colors, you pay six mana and what do you get? a five five and a decent boost to your creatures, followed by your opponent getting the same devastating boost should they survive. A very dissapointing end to my favorite magic story of all time.

4/5 for flavor, concept, and art. Admittedly it's a card you have to build heavily around though.

44263: Karona, False God.author: Arachnos
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
Use with Eon Hub. No upkeeps means that you get to keep her forever.

Barring Eon Hub and Vow of X shenanigans, you can think of her as a powerful finisher with a drawback if she doesn't finish, sort of like a multicolored Timbermare. +3/+3 to a tribe is nothing to scoff at. I'm thinking notably of Elves with Elvish Piper. Completely bypassing her restrictive mana cost, swing with her and your horde of elves, and drop Overrun while you're at it.

44263: Karona, False God.author: SAUS3
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
So my shadowborn apostle strategy got scrapped, and now my deck is basically voltron karona. There really aren't that many voltron cards in the deck, but that's because she is already strong the way she is. I run only 3 of the vows (5 was overkill and I was using them as pacifism which was inefficient).

Anyway, the deck is super awesome. If the setup is right, it's like a voltron commander with 4 combat steps per turn.

Grand melee + vow of wildness + elephant grass has been one of the most brutal things ever. I've also had lots of equipment thrown onto her as she goes by the voltron player's turn. He didn't mind getting all the jitte counters.

For funsies, I decided to try to include a ton of the charms from the ravnica block, alara block, and planeshift block. I have 13 in the deck. So many options! So much fun and so much chaos.

44263: Karona, False God.author: RAT666
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
hey "Lordrandomness" said:

"No matter what your opponent picks when they attack with her, all your stuff gets the bonus. Find one that can conveniently block her without killing, and there you go."

So are you saying that if I cast the Karona but my opponent has control it I to get to choose what creature type gets the bonus? So basically I cast Karona, I attack with her, creatures of my chosen type get the bonus. So when an opponent attacks I get to choose the creature types as well as my opponent when they control her and attack.

Also I have an idea. is there an artifact, and preferably a cheap artifact to play that has an ability to untap a creature? Attack with Karona after casting her then then use said artifact to untap at end step. Repeat.
Because if you realize this, each player (or your opponents) does not gain control of her if it's untapped.
Is there a card like ring of gix or icy manipulator that untaps instead of tapping?

Also is there a card to play that says "attacking doesn't cause creatures you control to tap?" That way other players cannot gain control of her...

Additionally @ comment "player 1: The Karona, False God that I exiled a few turns ago with Jhoira of the Ghitu resolves. I cast a kicked Rite of Replication on it, then copy the Rite twice with my level 4 Echo Mage. None of the Karonas die thanks to my Mirror Gallery. I swing with all 16 Karonas, naming Avatar with each of them and turning them into 53/53s." Why not?!
5 or 6 islands, a high tide and a couple of cheap colorless mana producing artifacts like sol ring or some thing else (because you card snobs will comment about the legality of sol ring and I hope my mentioning it will *** you off) would make the combo playable possibly somewhat early on. Also, you don't need jhoira of the ghitu if you don't attack with karona, false god.

44263: Karona, False God.author: Mockingbird_UK
44263: Karona, False God.text_parsed:
@RAT666:
hey "Lordrandomness" said:

"No matter what your opponent picks when they attack with her, all your stuff gets the bonus. Find one that can conveniently block her without killing, and there you go."

So are you saying that if I cast the Karona but my opponent has control it I to get to choose what creature type gets the bonus? So basically I cast Karona, I attack with her, creatures of my chosen type get the bonus. So when an opponent attacks I get to choose the creature types as well as my opponent when they control her and attack.

No. Lordrandomness was suggesting a "changeling" tribal deck - changleing creatures have all creature types at all times.

So your opponent who controls Karona can choose whatever they like (it is the current controller who chooses the creature type) and all of YOUR creatures will also be affected, because they are all creature types at the same time.

I feel like this is a really good legacy card (especially with counter spells); it's NOT good against combo. I'm thinking alongside Delver of Secrets, Young Pyromancer, Lightning Bolt and Daze etc. it just deals a really cost-efficient amount of damage until your opponent can't cast spells anymore (falls below 2).

Outside combo, the only played spells that DON'T trigger it are Force of Will, Batterskull, Terminus, Bloodbraid Elf, Jace, the Mind Sculptor, Submerge, Fireblast and Supreme Verdict.

For this reason, I prefer to use Goblin Grenades in my Goblin builds. Quite simply, its the more reliable and versatile card.

44292: Goblin War Strike.author: Nukeleo
44292: Goblin War Strike.text_parsed:
As a 1-of in my Pauper Storm deck it's been a surprise winner every time it has come up.

Step one: Storm out goblins.
Step two: Shoot.

With this in hand I can fire off MUCH sooner and need significantly less mana. If they have the ability to wipe my board I was dead anyway. Grapeshot requires one extra mana and does a fine job of being "that other way to win", but this is a terribly handy card.

44292: Goblin War Strike.author: CorkBulb
44292: Goblin War Strike.text_parsed:
In any decent goblins deck, this can seriously hurt. Such decks often put out a lot of cheap goblins and goblin tokens. And, with all the hasty goblins, they deal damage very rapidly and this may just be enough to deliver the fatal blow.

Combo with Krenko, Mob Boss and you've got a real finisher here.

Don't forget about Goblin Grenade. Although this can often do a lot more damage. This only targets the player though.

4.5/5 for goblin decks

44292: Goblin War Strike.author: donjohnson
44292: Goblin War Strike.text_parsed:
Just....wow.
One mana to end the game....draw two and kill two opponents without even attacking.

KillerNacho...not necessarily. There have been times when Ive had enough creatures to win, but wasnt able to attack safely because of leaving myself open to a second opponent if I tapped to attack the first.
This card does all that attack damage without forcing me to let my guard down. Secondly, in a case where I can do just over half damage needed to take a single opponent down, playing this first then attacking wins the game. Without it Id be all tapped out and still not win.
Hardly overrated. Ive seen what it can do.

44311: Dawn Elemental.author: SleetFox
44311: Dawn Elemental.text_parsed:
With Whispersilk Cloak, this essentially has "protection from everything." A miniature Progenitus, if you will.

What does protection mean?
-No damage. Dawn Elemental's built-in ability says this.
-No enchantment or equipment. Shroud from the cloak does this.
-Unblockable. The cloak says this.
-Untargetable. Shroud from the cloak.

So, as far as I know, there are no situations where this works differently from Progenitus, aside from the ability to block flying and do much less damage.
44311: Dawn Elemental.text_posted:
With [autocard]Whispersilk Cloak[/autocard], this essentially has "protection from everything."  A miniature [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard], if you will.

What does protection mean?
-No damage.  Dawn Elemental's built-in ability says this.
-No enchantment or equipment.  Shroud from the cloak does this.
-Unblockable.  The cloak says this.
-Untargetable.  Shroud from the cloak.

So, as far as I know, there are no situations where this works differently from Progenitus, aside from the ability to block flying and do much less damage.

Because, voice of all protects you fom one colour while this protetcs you from any kind of damage this creature would recieve, which means, that he's not gonna die because someone decided to Lightning Bolt him. This guy is also an perfect blocker, since he can block anything and not die, while your angel, can be pwned yb other colors.

This is a terrible card. It is so bad, that it got my inner johnny pumping, but then I got bored after I found that the obvious combos are functional without this.
Green is supposed to be the best accelerator, and yet there are many artifacts for four or less that get you or without being broken. Yes, the repeatable nature offers some combo potential, at the cost of making it criminally expensive for its intended purpose, and useless for your cheap spells.

44335: Decree of Annihilation.author: DarthParallax
44335: Decree of Annihilation.text_parsed:
This is probably going to rise in value in foil thanks to Avacyn, Griselbrand and Kaalia. Gentlemen, we have now reached a world where this feels like simply a reasonable sideboard card against horrendously broken stupidly powerful Dumb Shit.

Here's some good reasons to have this in your Commander 'sideboard' (ie your onhand binder of stuff.)

Kaalia of the Vast. Griselbrand. Venser's Journal. Avacyn. Worldslayer. Lich. yeah. (say in exact same voice Iron Man did in Avengers)

Griselbrand's Journal combo means you have to be able to exile hands (and probably graveyards, because Kaalia is going to be running big dumb creatures and has access to White and Black)

Avacyn + Lich + Worldslayer means you really need to be able exile the whole battlefield before you're overrun.

Enchantment + Planeswalker removal is something Red probably will never have.

Noobs: Worldfire is banned. Too bad you couldn't have known about that in July.
I'm not thinking of running this WITH Kaalia- specifically, anyway. I'm thinking of running this in any Commander deck that has Red, because there's some truly broken shit out there and you need a button to destroy EVERYTHING. Apocalypse is...errgh...needs better art. Yeah, I'm one of those guys that cares about art and flavortext and junk. >.>

@O0oze While you are right, this card is a reference to Karona, I still agree with Thoctar, it would fit really well in Zendikar, as the Kor hailed the Eldrazi as gods before they actually reawakened and started annihilating everything. Dawnglare Invoker's flavor text actually neatly encapsulates this point.

Emeria = Emrakul
Cosi = Kozilek
Ula = Ulamog

Thinking about it like that, actually makes me kinda sad that it didn't get reprinted, flavor-wise, at least.
A land that taps for 2 in a set that was designed around landfall.... It would have been a little ridiculous.

44339: Aphetto Runecaster.author: Drewskithelegend
44339: Aphetto Runecaster.text_parsed:
I play this in my yugioh deck. people keep flipping stuff up all the time and I'm just like... cool. Then these judges come around with a stick up their asses and explain that my sleeves should all be uniform in size etc. I cut the borders off and took a sharpie to the (3). It's a ritual monster now, I play it in Gishki. huehuehuehuehue

Protip: use in Empty Jar for maximum lulz.

Seriously though, great in Morph, where it rewards that extra mana investment. It's a shame you can't use it on cards like Zoetic Cavern though.

*To those of you who dismiss Yugioh as an inferior game, try it before you bash it. I played it for a while before I got into magic and I found both games to have a unique charm. In magic, creativity in deckbuilding tends to be more fruitful and games are often more fairly paced (i/e outside of eternal formats there are usually very few, if any, ways to lose a game on turn 1 or 2. In YGO it can happen on a scale of rarely to all the time, depending on how bad the banlist is, and even in the best formats you can get hit for lethal damage on turn 1-2 albiet very rarely.) On the other hand, top tier competitive YGO decks are fairly cheap in comparison to magic decks, with the most expensive decks often being close in price with the most expensive standard decks(advanced format is something like legacy or modern, where nearly every card in the game is permitted, however there are several that are restricted to 1 or 2 copies per deck.) Games can be more complex and more options are open much earlier in YGO, meaning that it is arguably more skill-intensive in regards to setup. Sets don't rotate out, which can be good or bad, depending on how much you hate certain decks, but on the other hand pretty much every card you own is legal for play at any time. If you like the idea of legacy but can't afford to play it, you would probably enjoy YGO a lot. YGO is also, in recent years, much more combo-oriented. There are few decks that just play a monster (creature) every turn and maybe drop a spell or 2 before passing, so in that respect, some Johnnies out there would probably find that they enjoy YGO also.

TL;DR Both games have their quirks, can't compare them side by side. YGO is cheaper, has more cards that you can do things with at any given time. Magic is more deckbuilding skill-intensive and tends to have a more reasonable game state than some YGO formats and a lot more cards that are actually worth playing. Cannot compare etc. etc. come at me bros.

44398: Eternal Dragon.author: SkaerKrow
44398: Eternal Dragon.text_parsed:
@Justice1337

Wouldn't be played in today's standard? Given ISD block's penchant for graveyard manipulation and its support for Spirit tribal, I think you're dead wrong on that one. Eternal Dragon fetches part of the Flashback cost of Unburial Rites and hits the table as a 6/6 Hexproof flying creature if you have out a Drogskol Captain (and if you're playing Spirits in standard right now, you're probably running a full set of captains). It's not the world-beater than it used to be, but it's still a fine card that holds up to scrutiny even now. Considering how old the card is, that's saying something for its design.

44398: Eternal Dragon.author: BenderGameboy
44398: Eternal Dragon.text_parsed:
What's with all the mono white comments? Has anyone noticed it searches a "plains" card, not a basic land? I point this out because the cycling ability is perfect for fixing in a Kaalia of the Vast EDH deck.

Colorless cycling to get any plains based dual land from your deck, either Plateau, Scrubland, Godless Shrine, or Sacred Foundry - whichever you one need. It will even get you another one later if you're missing land drops (happens to the best of us) by paying the 5 mana cost upkeep and cycling again whenever possible. Options are better than nothing in that situation.

Topdeck or reanimate it late game with Kaalia out and you've got a free 5/5 flyer on the attack. Show me another creature based (angel/demon/dragon*) fixer with those specs... Really, I'd like to know. 5/5

*Bonus

44398: Eternal Dragon.author: Haelthor
44398: Eternal Dragon.text_parsed: Not as good as it once was, but that's back before we had the modern card frame. Works with Astral Slide + Eternal Witness (this was actually an engine a world champion deck used to get his side of the table set up). As @BenderGameboy pointed out its a single card with at least 4 -relevant- abilities tacked onto it. There's a saying about magic along the lines of: The more solid options a player has with his/her cards, turn after turn, the greater the chance of victory. Eternal Dragon fixes/accels/thins during the early-mid game (possibly returning just so you can pitch it again) then saunters on into the battlefield after a few Day of Judgement and clocks your opponent in 4 turns. Card Advantage + Versatility = Winning!

44401: Reward the Faithful.author: Monty_Sigurdson
44401: Reward the Faithful.text_parsed:
@console gamer: No, it's not better than Healing Salve since a) you need to control a permanent with CMC > 3 in order to gain more life than you would with Healing Salve and b) Healing Salve can also prevent damage to creatures or players which can be a useful combat trick.

That said, this card only really fits in very specific decks (maybe Lifegain decks or decks that abuse high CMC); also it's very useful in multiplayer since you can target as many players as you want.

Personally I prefer Healing Salve over this in all other cases. However, this can definitely be a very handy card, plus the art is very funny.

3/5

44401: Reward the Faithful.author: MattLynn
44401: Reward the Faithful.text_parsed: This reminds me of a free join forces type card that is very political. If you're using Gilded Drake, Bazaar Trader, and Goblin Welder in a Zedruu, the Greathearted deck. When multiplayer games are large enough, players need to decide who will ally with them based on personal preferences & deck capabilities. Think of it like this: out of everybody playing, which ones do you want to go down last vs you? Ally with them. Donate to them and give them spirit tokens with Forbidden Orchard, etc. People do this already on MMORPG's...because no one person is an army. There isn't much that Armageddon, Wrath of God or Mindslaver can't fix one on one later with your ally-turned-sole-enemy. In commander, this easily gains 5-6 life per chosen player for , not bad, but most wouldn't put it on an Isochron Scepter without Well of Lost Dreams, however. Just consider the cost of this vs the potential...

45138: Force Bubble.author: grothesk
45138: Force Bubble.text_parsed:
The design of this card leans towards faux card draw for White: this card will most likely eat up an attack phase which means that you've slow-tripped/fogged for 4 mana.

It should be noted Force Bubble is quite effective on shutting down small "on hit" creatures. Hypnotic Specter and Thada Adel, Acquisitor will simply get shrugged off and if your opponents happen to get some heavy hitting "on hit" creatures such as Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni or Living Hive online it at least gives you a turn to find an answer (or wait for the most opportune time to use your answer already in hand.)

45139: Daru Spiritualist.author: ddde
45139: Daru Spiritualist.text_parsed:
I also do the same as Tigrex. It's a wonderful combo. Technically it does not win you the game, but in practice it usually will. Very few decks have realistic win conditions other then taking all of their opponents' life. It's theoretically possible to be using cards that set an opponents' life to a specific number, but again, very few decks can do that either. Other then that, your only real hope is that your opponent can't do enough damage to bring you down to 0 life before he runs out of cards.

Of course, it's a three card combo. Not all that likely to come up. There are, however, other en-kor creatures that could set up the damage shields by targeting a cleric 93287483638754 times, and a few other cards that allow you to sac a creature to gain life eual to its toughness. I don't think there are any other substitutes for this card though.

45139: Daru Spiritualist.author: roguepariah
45139: Daru Spiritualist.text_parsed:
It is a fun combo, and it can be done in a variety of ways with several different cards.

Worthy cause, condemn, and miren, the moaning well are a few of the alternatives for starlit sanctum that aren't cleric specific.
angelic protector, and task force will fill the role of the spiritualist
Any of the en-kor creatures can be used to set up the infinite loop. Lightning greaves will also work but requires an additional creature on the board. Shuko can get the job done cheaper than the greaves and without the extra creature, but works at sorcery speed compared to the en-kor creatures activated abilities.

All that being said, the combo with the spiritualist, sanctum, and nomads en-kor will get you there fastest at turn 3. not to mention that the spiritualist has a huge number of clerics to work with in tribal.

45139: Daru Spiritualist.author: crashnburn99
45139: Daru Spiritualist.text_parsed:
My friend made a pretty sweet cleric deck that uses the infinite life combo and I am trying to understand it completely, so a few questions if you all don't mind. I understand that one could play the ability and give his/her cleric +0/+2, let it resolve then do it again and again, then play the starlit sanctum for life. Now, if someone decided to use one stack and do the ability over and over then use the starlit sanctum in the same stack, would the +0/+2 abilities resolve or would they only get life based on the original toughness do to the other abilities not resolving?

Another question I have, my friend mentioned that "the game action of the sacrificing the creature starts a new stack and the life gaining ability is on that stack", is this true or would it just fall into the current stack that is taking place?

Thank you all in advance for any information you can provide.

45141: Decree of Justice.author: Gabriel422
45141: Decree of Justice.text_parsed:
A really powerful card that I played a bit too, but one of the cards that I dislike. It's too swingy for my liking, and casting a Decree for 8 followed by another one for 10 next turn against a bunch of Goblins is not even fun for me the caster. It's just big and dumb, like a bunch of angelic tyrants.

Guess this is what I hate about white, more than any of the other four colors - White has no teamwork and almost no synergy. You simply play one powerful spell after another, each one having nothing to do with the next. There's no Elvish Archdruid into Eldrazi Monument / Genesis Wave / Joraga Warcaller, to vastly different results and specializations. Nothing that makes you feel clever like Smoldering Spire plus Kiln Fiend, or the way-too-many tricks you can perform with blue cards. The closest thing to synergy in white with any regularity is probably tokens + team boosting effects, but it's too old and pretty much every color has this. White cards tend to be the most boring, and white only competes because it's given the best stats and casting costs to make up for its lack of synergy.

45141: Decree of Justice.author: dberry02
45141: Decree of Justice.text_parsed:
This card has won me games simply because it's an uncounterable instant speed soldier drop that even lets you draw a card! Think of this card like an uncounterable White Sun's Zenith that allows you to draw and gives you 1/1 soldiers rather than 2/2 cats. It also gives you the option to get 4/4 angels with evasion (which is rarely needed btw - maybe as anti-air defenders?).

This has worked wonders in my white weenie deck. I would cycle Decree at the end of my opponent's turn. Then on my turn, I would drop one or more Glorious Anthems and swing. Most people won't expect buffed soldiers next turn for the simple fact that most token generation is slow and predictable.

45164: Ancient Ooze.author: AncientOoze
45164: Ancient Ooze.text_parsed: Mythic Proportions is an amazing card for this, as is Mosstodon, but even a Roughshod Mentor can do the trick, and it costs one more than a Mosstodon, so Ancient Ooze will be +1/+1 greater if you have a Mentor instead. A Spearbreaker Behemoth can also be a good friend, as can a Protean Hulk because he makes Ancient Ooze beyond epic when he goes to the graveyard. Also, in a deck where mana cost matters, one might want to throw in a Manaplasm for when he plays those big fatty monsters. Another fun trick is playinga Krosan Colossus face-down and flipping it up after Ancient Ooze is declared as an attacker to give Ancient Ooze +9/+9 on an attack. With trample, that could win one the game. Another game winner especially potent with Ancient Ooze is Decree of Savagery. Whether it gets played or cycled (depending on how much mana is available) it can help push Ancient Ooze over the edge to win the game, or at least bring victory that much closer. I think it's essential though that Ooze have trample because, like Wolf-blood said, it pretty much always plays for something over twenty.

45835: Wing Shards.author: kiseki
45835: Wing Shards.text_parsed:
I am very picky, and I have low regard for most of the cards in existence. However, there are a few cards that rise head and shoulders above the rest for cards that I loathe. All of the "target player sacrifices an attacking creature" cards are on that list.
These aren't answer cards, these aren't strategic cards. They are crazy lame cards that make you second guess attacking with only your best creature EVERY attack of EVERY game. They don't have much power, really, as far as removal goes, but occasionally they gank the attacking player in spectacular fashion.
I am not disappointed by counterspells, direct removal, or having my combos spoiled, but this mechanic irks me. They reprint it just often enough that I can't forget it, but you can't play intelligently around this card. Does a good player see three untapped plains and think "I'm going to attack with my dragon, and throw my goblins in as well even though most won't survive just to protect my dragon"? No, because if they did that for every attack of every game they would lose more games than assuming your opponent doesn't have it would.
This card adds luck to the game at the expense of skill.

45835: Wing Shards.author: Drewsel
45835: Wing Shards.text_parsed:
This is directed towards Mr.kiseki;

When was Magic ever a strategy game? You start the game off by randomly pulling seven cards from your deck and decide whether or not to roll with it. The rest of the game is decided upon single random draws. You must be playing an entirely different sort of Magic if you think you're applying strategy. 45835: Wing Shards.author: Myrdden
45835: Wing Shards.text_parsed:
Directed toward Drewsel,

Strategy is all over the place in Magic, like playing your spells in your second main phase rather than your first so as to not feed your opponent's Wing Shards spells or other spells with Storm. Simple strategy perhaps, but strategy none-the-less. Not wasting an Echoing Truth on a small nibbler and using it on a larger, costlier creature later is a better strategy than wasting it early on. Using a trickery charm to see the one card an opponent has in hand before making them discard a card that just might be better in their graveyard than in their hand is definitely a fine strategy.

Point is, there is much random luck in the game, but there is good thinking, and bad thinking, in the play of the game. Good strategy, or bad strategy. Knowing when to play a spell and when to not play it is definitely strategy. I've used Magic to teach my students strategy for years now. In multiplayer games, this is much more necessary, as there is a lot of psychology involved in bluffing, making alliances, keeping your options open, etc. I mostly play multiplayer games, so I guess I see more of the strategies involved in playing Magic than strict duelers might.

45836: Temporal Fissure.author: blurrymadness
45836: Temporal Fissure.text_parsed:
T3 with three islands
High Tide
Cloud of Faeries
Snap (floating 2 mana) (between your islands and your floating mana you can now rewind or counterspell for the rest of the combo)
Cloud of Faeries (floating 4 mana)
Temporal Fissure (Bounce up to 5 permanents, including cloud of faeries (if you want/need more mana) (floating 5 mana) (use your islands)
Cloud of Faeries (floating 7 mana) (if you want)
Tidespout Tyrant (Bounce permanents every turn for the rest of the game)
(up to 5 mana left, depending..)

Have 1 mana left over. Keep remands ready and you'll gain mana if they attempt to counter anything after step 3 or so. It may be a bit of a god-hand.. but if your deck is built around that sort of thing you could combo-out quite quickly. Consider boomerang and such to keep the opponent in a bad position right from the start. Also, Delver

If you don't have all of the cards above, you can easily just high-tide, CoF, and Temporal Fissure (1 mana open) to bounce all (3) of your opponent's lands. If you have something else you'd like to cast, you went first, or you've already bounce a land, you can instead bounce the faeries back to your hand. Keep brain freeze in the deck on the chance you accidentally "go off" for too much mana. Delver + control cards means that you can get by as a control deck instead of a combo deck fairly easily. Sideboard Marrow Shards and Surgical Extraction for mono-blue controlling of other problem decks.

45842: Tendrils of Agony.author: Atali
45842: Tendrils of Agony.text_parsed:
@Superllama
Those things might happen in Vintage, but never anywhere else. The only card you mentioned that ever shared standard with Tendrils of Agony is Ornithopter. Even Dark Ritual was last printed four years before Tendrils.
Also, you would need an absurdly perfect draw to pull off a win the way you describe.

Realistically, Tendrils of Agony is a finisher in a U/B control deck. Control the board until you can storm up enough for a kill (perhaps using Mind's Desire?).

45842: Tendrils of Agony.author: TheShadow344
45842: Tendrils of Agony.text_parsed:
First turn:

Swamp
Dark Ritual
Entomb, search for Griselbrand
Exhume or Animate Dead to put Griselbrand on the battlefield
Pay 14 life, draw 14 cards
Lotus Petal
Memnite or Putrid Imp
Culling the Weak
Dark Ritual
Any card with CMC 0 or 1
Any card with CMC 0 or 1
Tendrils of Agony for 20 life

GG

As long as you can get the first turn Dark Ritual into Entomb and Exhume / Animate Dead, you can usually combo off right then and there. And in multiplayer, the first Tendrils allows you to draw more cards and keep the combo going! Current record is 520 damage on the first turn (Yawgmoth's Will is in the deck too for the lulz).

Only downside is that I no longer have friends.

45843: Scattershot.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
45843: Scattershot.text_parsed:
It goes without saying that this card looks extremely underwhelming if you're forced to play it with no storm count. I would guess that Grapeshot and this are really built to be played in different situations.

You'd go with Grapeshot if you had built your deck to cast a slew of cards on the same turn - it's much more of a combo piece, in my mind. Scattershot, on the other hand, seems like something you'd play to punish your opponent for a combo of his/her own.
45843: Scattershot.text_posted:

45847: Sprouting Vines.author: tankplanker
45847: Sprouting Vines.text_parsed: A bit situtational for normal games as it works best against decks playing lots of spells so I'd keep it in the sideboard. Where this card comes alive is in Archenemy as all the opponets share the same turn, works as either the team (play it in your turn) or as the Archenemy (play it in their turn). Played right and you'll get at least three lands, played well and you'll get many more. Couple it with Burgeoning to make the most of all that land in Archenemy.

45847: Sprouting Vines.author: Jannissary
45847: Sprouting Vines.text_parsed:
When I first opened this I was excited, and then I realized that it just goes into your hand.

So I put it back into the Pile of Shame, where the cards that never see play go. It's still there, probably, about three moves and many years later, sitting in an unopened box in an attic. Somebody in 10-20 years, when my parents die and we come to distribute their belongings, will open the box and go "Oh wow, look at those magic cards," get to this one, and then say "Holy crap this card sucks."

45862: Vengeful Dead.author: pumaman83
45862: Vengeful Dead.text_parsed: @FFXIK  Actually tokens trigger "put into graveyard" effects before they cease to exist.  Thus the Tombstone Stairwell should work.
45862: Vengeful Dead.text_posted: @FFXIK  Actually tokens trigger "put into graveyard" effects before they cease to exist.  Thus the Tombstone Stairwell should work.

45862: Vengeful Dead.author: rulesinquisitor
45862: Vengeful Dead.text_parsed: FFXIK: pumaman and holgir are correct. Tokens cease to exist if they end up in any zone other than the battlefield (owner's hand or graveyard, usually), but they DO trigger any applicable abilities before disappearing. So, zombie tokens from Tombstone Stairwell or Zombie Infestation would trigger Vengeful Dead's ability if they were destroyed by the Stairwell leaving play or if they were sacked by Nantuko Husk's ability, as GruesomeGoo suggested. They would not, however, count toward Mortivore's P/T or any other card that cared about the number of creatures in a graveyard, because they would no longer exist once they leave play. Even a "flicker" effect, like Venser, the Sojourner's first ability would effectively exile token permanents, permanently.

45862: Vengeful Dead.author: FFXIK
45862: Vengeful Dead.text_parsed:
The rules I was quoting from were quite old. "If any effect takes a token out of play, remove it from the game. You can't send a token to the graveyard, return it to your hand, or otherwise maintain it out of play.

That excerpt is taken from a rules insert in the Ice Age expansion. Proof that I was out of the loop for far to long and proved my ignorance on the newer rule revisions that have come about since then. I have since gotten quite familliar with the rulebook in hope to keep this kind of thing from happening again.
